Formal Methods and Functional Programming, Quiz 1, SS23 3Formal Methods and Functional Programming, Quiz 1, SS23 4 Assignment 2 (10 points) The famous Collatz conjecture says that for all n ∈ N, the sequence u(n) deﬁned by u(n)0 = n ∀k ∈ N. u(n)k+1 = ¢¨¨ ¦ ¨¨¤ u(n)k 2 if u(n)k is even 3u(n)k + 1 if u(n)k is odd always eventually reaches 1, i.e., for all n, there exists k0 ∈ N such that u(n)k0 = 1. The smallest such k0 is called the stopping time of n and denoted by st(n). For example, for n = 3, the sequence u(3) is 3, 10, 5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1, . . . , hence st(3) = 7. Write a Haskell function bst :: Int -> Int -> Int such that bst n m returns min(st(n), m). In other words, the function should return the stopping time of n if it is strictly smaller than m, and m otherwise. Formal Methods and Functional Programming, Quiz 1, SS23 5
